member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.XmppStream.SetCertificateFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Sets the certificate to be used for accept sockets. To generate a test .pfx file using OpenSSL, add this to openssl.conf:
[ serverex ] extendedKeyUsage=1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1
and run the following commands:
openssl req -new -x509 -newkey rsa:1024 -keyout privkey.pem -out key.pem -extensions serverex openssl pkcs12 -export -in key.pem -inkey privkey.pem -name localhost -out localhost.pfx
If you leave the certificate null, and you are doing Accept, the SSL class will try to find a default server certificate on your box.
member.param: The password, if this is a .pfx file, null if .cer file.

member.summary: Sends a presence packet to the XMPP server.

A list of groups to put the contact in. May be null. Hint: new string[] {"foo", "bar"}

member.summary: Removes a contact from the roster. This will also remove the subscription for that contact being removed.

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.GetAgents
member.summary: Requests a list of agents from the XMPP server.

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.Register(Jabber.JID)
member.summary: Attempts to register a new user. This will fire OnRegisterInfo to retrieve information about the new user, and OnRegistered when the registration is completed or failed.

member.summary: Sorts the XML element looking for Presence, Message, and IQ packets.
member.param: The XML element containing a stanza.

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.FireAuthError(System.Xml.XmlElement)
member.summary: Informs the client that an error occurred during authentication. This is public so that manual authenticators can fire errors using the same events.
member.param: Xml element containing the error message.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnPresence
member.summary: Informs the client that it received a presence packet.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnMessage
member.summary: Informs the client that it received a message packet.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnIQ
member.summary: Informs the client that it received an IQ packet.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnAuthError
member.summary: Informs the client that the authentication has failed. The connection is not terminated if there is an authentication error, and there is at least one event handler for this event.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnBeforePresenceOut
member.summary: Informs the client that the presence is about to be sent. This gives a chance to modify outbound presence (fore example, entity caps).

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnAfterPresenceOut
member.summary: Informs the client that the presence has been sent. This gives a chance to send presence to other things, such as chat rooms.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnLoginRequired
member.summary: Determines if AutoLogin is false, and if it is time to log in. This callback will receive the results of the IQ type=get in the jabber:iq:auth namespace. When login is completed, IsConnected property is set to true. If there is a login error, the FireAuthError() method is called.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnRegistered
member.summary: Informs the client if the registration succeeded or failed.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OnRegisterInfo
member.summary:
Allows the user to enter registration requested information before sending to the XMPP server.
WARNING: Make sure you do not return from this handler until the IQ is filled in. It is now safe to call UI elements, since this callback is now on the GUI thread if the InvokeControl is set.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.OfflineStatus
member.summary: Retrieves/Sets the status sent when user disconnects

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.User
member.summary: Retrieves/Sets the username to connect as.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.Priority
member.summary: Gets the priority for this connection.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.Password
member.summary: Gets or sets the password to use for connecting to the XMPP server. This may be sent across the wire plaintext if the XMPP server doesn't support digest and PlaintextAuth is set to true.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.AutoLogin
member.summary: Allows auto-login to be used for the connection to the XMPP server if set to true.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.AutoRoster
member.summary: Retrieves the roster on connection.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.AutoIQErrors
member.summary: Sends 501/feature-not-implemented back to the client when an IQ has not been handled if set to true.

member.name: P:Jabber.Client.JabberClient.AutoPresence
member.summary: Sends presence information when the connection has been established if set to true.

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JingleManager.OnReceivedSessionInitiate
member.summary:
Informs the client that it received a session-initiate IQ packet This event is fired after XMPP acknowledge message has been sent
If the IQ has been handled by subscribed event handlers the received message is added to sessions dictionary Else a session-terminate message with decline reason is sent

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JingleManager.OnReceivedSessionAccept
member.summary:
Informs the client that it received a session-accept IQ packet This event is fired after XMPP acknowledge message has been sent
If the IQ has been handled by subscribed event handlers the received message is added to sessions dictionary Else a session-terminate message with cancel reason is sent

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JingleManager.OnReceivedSessionTerminate
member.summary:
Informs the client that it received a session-terminate IQ packet This event is fired after XMPP acknowledge message has been sent
Whatever the IQ has been handled or not by subscribed event handlers the session is removed from sessions dictionary

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JingleManager.OnReceivedSessionInfo
member.summary:
Informs the client that it received a session-info IQ packet
If the IQ has not been handled by subscribed event handlers an XMPP acknowledge is sent back

member.name: E:Jabber.Client.JingleManager.OnReceivedTransportInfo
member.summary:
Informs the client that it received a transport-info IQ packet
If the IQ has not been handled by subscribed event handlers an XMPP acknowledge is sent back

member.summary: Gets the current presence state as a string.
member.returns: string in the format '{bare JID}={list of presence stanzas}, ...'

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.AddPresence(Jabber.Protocol.Client.Presence)
member.summary: Adds a new available or unavailable presence packet to the database.

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.IsAvailable(Jabber.JID)
member.summary: Determines if a specified JID is online with any resources. This performs better than retrieving the particular associated presence packet.
member.returns: If true, the user is online; otherwise the user is offline

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.GetFeatures(Jabber.JID)
member.summary:
Get the features associated with the JID. If a bare JID is passed in, this will be a union of all of the features for all of the resources of this user. Otherwise, it will be the features for the given resource.
Requires a CapsManager to be set before use.
member.returns: Null if no features are known.

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.HasFeature(Jabber.JID,System.String)
member.summary:
Does the given JID implement the given feature? Bare JID asks if any resource of that user implements that feature. Full JID asks if the given resource implements that feature.
Requires a CapsManager to be set before use.
member.returns: True if the feaure is implemented

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.GetFeatureJID(Jabber.JID,System.String)
member.summary: Get the most available full JID that implements the given feature. Unlike most routines in PresenceManager, may also return JIDs that have negative presence. If a full JID is specified, this is effectively the same as HasFeature, but null will be returned if the feature isn't implemented.
member.returns: null if none found

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.GetAll(Jabber.JID)
member.summary: Gets all of the current presence stanzas for the given user.
member.param: User who's presence stanzas you want.
member.returns: Array of presence stanzas for the given user.

member.name: M:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.System#Collections#IEnumerable#GetEnumerator
member.summary: Iterate over all of the JIDs we have not-unavilable presence from.

member.summary: Return the total number of presences including each connected resource

member.name: T:Jabber.Client.PresenceManager.UserPresenceManager
member.summary:
Manage the presence for all of the resources of a user. No locking is performed, since PresenceManager is already doing locking.
The intent of this class is to be able to deliver the last presence stanza from the "most available" resource. Note that negative priority sessions are never the most available.

member.summary: Joins a conference room.

member.summary: Determines whether or not the conference room is being managed by this ConferenceManager.
member.returns: True if the room is being managed.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.RemoveRoom(Jabber.JID)
member.summary: Removes the room from the list. Should most often be called by the Room.Leave() method. If the room does not exist, no exception is thrown.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.GetUniqueRoom(System.String,System.String,Jabber.Connection.RoomStateEvent,System.Object)
member.summary:
Get a unique room name from the given server, and create a Room object for that room with the given nick. You'll be called back on "callback" when complete; the Room will be null if there was an error or timeout.
Note: the server should implement the feature http://jabber.org/protocol/muc#unique, or this will return an error. To work around, just create a room with a Guid for a name.
member.param: The server to send the request to
The nickname desired in the new room
A callback to be called when the room is created
State object to be passed back when the callback fires

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnJoin
member.summary: Finished joining the room, including all potential configuration. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnLeave
member.summary: Finished leaving the room, or was kicked/banned, or the room server went down cleanly. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnPresenceError
member.summary: Error in response to a room join, nick change, or presence update. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnRoomConfig
member.summary: Room configuration form received. It is up to the listener call FinishConfig(). The IQ in the callback is the parent of the x:data element. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnRoomMessage
member.summary: A message broadcast to all in the room If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnPrivateMessage
member.summary: A side-chat message. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnAdminMessage
member.summary: An admin message from the room itself. Typically status change sorts of things like kick/ban. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnSelfMessage
member.summary: A message that was sent by this user to the room, echo'd back. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnSubjectChange
member.summary: The subject of the room has been changed If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnParticipantJoin
member.summary: A participant has joined the room. This will not fire for yourself. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnParticipantLeave
member.summary: A participant has left the room. This will not fire for yourself. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnPresenceChange
member.summary: You have changed presence, without joining or leaving the room. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnParticipantPresenceChange
member.summary: A participant has changed presence, without joining or leaving the room. This will not fire for yourself. If set, will be added to each room created through the manager.

member.name: E:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.OnInvite
member.summary: An invite was received. A room object will be passed in as the sender.

member.name: P:Jabber.Connection.ConferenceManager.DefaultNick
member.summary: The default room nickname, if one is not specified. If none specified, the user name from the stream JID is used.

member.name: M:Jabber.Protocol.Element.GetOrCreateElement``1
member.summary:
If a child element exists with the given type, return it. Otherwise, gin up a new instance of the given type, add it as a child, and return the result.
This should not have the performance impact of GetOrCreateElement.

member.name: M:Jabber.Protocol.Element.GetOrCreateElement(System.String,System.String,System.Type)
member.summary: If the named element exists as a child, return it. Otherwise, gin up a new instance of the given class (which must be a subclass of XmlElement) add it as a child, and return the result. Will often be paired with ReplaceChild as the setter.
member.remarks: This seems kind of around-the-barn. Wish there was an easier way to do this, rather than having to get the constructor, and whatnot. Hopefully it won't be called all that often, so the speed issue won't be too bad.
member.param: Namespace URI. Null to use parent's.
If the element doesn't exist, create it with this type. If null, then just use an XmlElement.

member.returns: The replaced element

member.name: M:Jabber.Protocol.Client.IQ.GetResponse(System.Xml.XmlDocument,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Swap the to and from, set the type to result and append Query element if wanted (eg: XEP-0199 (Ping) and XEP-0166 (Jingle) sends ack IQs responses who do not contains any Query element inside the response)

member.summary: Has this IQ been handled? Set automatically by GetResponse and GetErrorResponse. If this is not set to true, Jabber-Net will respond automatically with a 501 error.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.Jingle.Initiator
member.summary: The full JID of the entity that has initiated the session flow. When the Jingle action is "session-initiate", the element SHOULD possess an 'initiator' attribute that explicitly specifies the full JID of the initiating entity; For all other actions, the element SHOULD NOT possess an 'initiator' attribute and the recipient of the message SHOULD ignore the value if provided

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.Jingle.Responder
member.summary: The full JID of the entity that has replied to the initiation, which can be different from the 'to' address on the IQ-set. When the Jingle action is "session-accept", the element SHOULD possess a 'responder' attribute that explicitly specifies the full JID of the responding entity; For all other actions, the element SHOULD NOT possess a 'responder' attribute and the recipient of the message SHOULD ignore the value if provided

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.Jingle.Sid
member.summary: A random session identifier generated by the initiator, which effectively maps to the local-part of a SIP "Call-ID" parameter

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.Jingle.Action
member.summary: The jingle action

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.Jingle.Reason
member.summary: Machine-readable information about the condition that prompted the action.

member.name: T:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType
member.summary: Types of actions. This enum doesn't exactly match the XEP, since most of the field types aren't valid identifiers in C#.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.UNSPECIFIED
member.summary: None specified

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.content_accept
member.summary: The content-accept action is used to accept a content-add action received from another party

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.content_add
member.summary: The content-add action is used to add one or more new content definitions to the session

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.content_modify
member.summary: The content-modify action is used to change the direction of an existing content definition through modification of the 'senders' attribute

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.content_reject
member.summary: The content-reject action is used to reject a content-add action received from another party

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.content_remove
member.summary: The content-remove action is used to remove one or more content definitions from the session

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.description_info
member.summary: The description-info action is used to send informational hints about parameters related to the application type, such as the suggested height and width of a video display area or suggested configuration for an audio stream

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.security_info
member.summary: The security-info action is used to send information related to establishment or maintenance of security preconditions

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.session_accept
member.summary: The session-accept action is used to definitively accept a session negotiation (implicitly this action also serves as a content-accept)

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.session_info
member.summary: The session-info action is used to send session-level information, such as a session ping or (for Jingle RTP sessions) a ringing message.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.session_initiate
member.summary: The session-initiate action is used to request negotiation of a new Jingle session

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.session_terminate
member.summary: The session-terminate action is used to end an existing session

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.transport_accept
member.summary: The transport-accept action is used to accept a transport-replace action received from another party

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.transport_info
member.summary: The transport-info action is used to exchange transport candidates; it is mainly used in Jingle ICE-UDP but might be used in other transport specifications.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.transport_reject
member.summary: The transport-reject action is used to reject a transport-replace action received from another party

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ActionType.transport_replace
member.summary: The transport-replace action is used to redefine a transport method, typically for fallback to a different method (e.g., changing from ICE-UDP to Raw UDP for a datagram transport, or changing from SOCKS5 Bytestreams [26] to In-Band Bytestreams [27] for a streaming transport)

member.summary: Machine-readable information about the condition that prompted the action.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.alternative_session
member.summary: The party prefers to use an existing session with the peer rather than initiate a new session; the Jingle session ID of the alternative session SHOULD be provided as the XML character data of the child

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.busy
member.summary: The party is busy and cannot accept a session

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.cancel
member.summary: The initiator wishes to formally cancel the session initiation request

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.connectivity_error
member.summary: The action is related to connectivity problems

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.decline
member.summary: The party wishes to formally decline the session

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.expired
member.summary: The session length has exceeded a pre-defined time limit (e.g., a meeting hosted at a conference service)

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.failed_application
member.summary: The party has been unable to initialize processing related to the application type

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.failed_transport
member.summary: The party has been unable to establish connectivity for the transport method

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.general_error
member.summary: The action is related to a non-specific application error

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.gone
member.summary: The entity is going offline or is no longer available

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.incompatible_parameters
member.summary: The party supports the offered application type but does not support the offered or negotiated parameters

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.media_error
member.summary: The action is related to media processing problems

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.security_error
member.summary: The action is related to a violation of local security policies

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.success
member.summary: The action is generated during the normal course of state management and does not reflect any error

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.timeout
member.summary: A request has not been answered so the sender is timing out the request.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.unsupported_applications
member.summary: The party supports none of the offered application types

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.IQ.ReasonType.unsupported_transports
member.summary: The party supports none of the offered transport methods

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCode
member.summary: The ERROR-CODE attribute is used in error response messages. It contains a numeric error code value in the range of 300 to 699 plus a textual reason phrase encoded in UTF-8, and is consistent in its code assignments and semantics with SIP [RFC3261] and HTTP [RFC2616] ErrorCodes referenced are STUN [RFC5389], TURN [RFC5766], TURN-TCP [RFC6062], TURN-IPV6 [RFC6156], ICE [RFC5245] and STUN Classic [RFC3489]

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.StunAttribute
member.summary: Represents a message attribute according to STUN [RFC5389], TURN [RFC5766], TURN-TCP [RFC6062], TURN-IPV6 [RFC6156], ICE [RFC5245] and STUN Classic [RFC3489]

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCode.Class
member.summary: The Class represents the hundreds digit of the error code. The value MUST be between 3 and 6

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCode.Code
member.summary: The Number represents the error code modulo 100, and its value MUST be between 0 and 99.

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCode.Reason
member.summary: The reason phrase is meant for user consumption, and can be anything appropriate for the error code. Recommended reason phrases for the defined error codes are included in the IANA registry for error codes. The reason phrase MUST be a UTF-8 [RFC3629] encoded sequence of less than 128 characters (which can be as long as 763 bytes).

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCode.ErrorTypeShort
member.summary: Represents the entire error code, the class * 100 + the code

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCode.ErrorType
member.summary: Represents the ErrorCodeType enum of this ERROR-CODE attribute based on the ErrorTypeValue

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType
member.summary: Enumeration of any STUN errors types Each error type has a matching constant defined in STUN [RFC5389], in TURN [RFC5766] or in SIP [3261]

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.Unmanaged
member.summary: Represents errors whose type is not managed by this library

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.TryAlternate
member.summary: The client should contact an alternate server for this request. This error response MUST only be sent if the request included a USERNAME attribute and a valid MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute; otherwise, it MUST NOT be sent and error code 400 (Bad Request) is suggested. This error response MUST be protected with the MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute, and receivers MUST validate the MESSAGE-INTEGRITY of this response before redirecting themselves to an alternate server

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.BadRequest
member.summary: The request was malformed. The client SHOULD NOT retry the request without modification from the previous attempt. The server may not be able to generate a valid MESSAGE-INTEGRITY for this error, so the client MUST NOT expect a valid MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute on this response

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.Unauthorized
member.summary: The request did not contain the correct credentials to proceed The client should retry the request with proper credentials

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.UnknownAttribute
member.summary: The server received a STUN packet containing a comprehension-required attribute that it did not understand The server MUST put this unknown attribute in the UNKNOWN-ATTRIBUTE attribute of its error response

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.StaleNonce
member.summary: The NONCE used by the client was no longer valid The client should retry, using the NONCE provided in the response

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.ServerError
member.summary: The server has suffered a temporary error. The client should try again.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.Forbidden
member.summary: The request was valid but cannot be performed due to administrative or similar restrictions

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.AllocationMismatch
member.summary: A request was received by the server that requires an allocation to be in place, but no allocation exists, or a request was received that requires no allocation, but an allocation exists.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.WrongCredentials
member.summary: The credentials in the (non-Allocate) request do not match those used to create the allocation.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.UnsupportedTransportProtocol
member.summary: The Allocate request asked the server to use a transport protocol between the server and the peer that the server does not support. NOTE: This does NOT refer to the transport protocol used in the 5-tuple.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.AllocationQuotaReached
member.summary: No more allocations using this username can be created at the present time.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.InsufficientCapacity
member.summary: The server is unable to carry out the request due to some capacity limit being reached. In an Allocate response, this could be due to the server having no more relayed transport addresses available at that time, having none with the requested properties, or the one that corresponds to the specified reservation token is not available.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.ConnectionAlreadyExists
member.summary: The server receives a Connect request but it's already processing a Connect request or has already successfully processed a Connect request for the allocation with the same XOR-PEER-ADDRESS, and the resulting client and peer data connections are either pending or active

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.ConnectionTimeoutOrFailure
member.summary: The TURN server was unable to connect to the peer

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.AddressFamilyNotSupported
member.summary: The server does not support the address family requested by a client

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.PeerAddresFamilyMismatch
member.summary: The server receives a Refresh Request with a REQUESTED-ADDRESS-FAMILY attribute, and the attribute's value doesn't match the address family of the allocation

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.RoleConflict
member.summary: The client asserted an ICE role (controlling or controlled) that is in conflict with the role of the server.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.MethodNotAllowed
member.summary: The method specified in the Request-Line is understood, but not allowed for the address identified by the Request-URI The response MUST include an Allow header field containing a list of valid methods for the indicated address

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.StaleCredentials
member.summary: The Binding Request did contain a MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute, but it used a shared secret that has expired. The client should obtain a new shared secret and try again.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.IntegrityCheckFailure
member.summary: The Binding Request contained a MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute, but the HMAC failed verification. This could be a sign of a potential attack, or client implementation error.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.MissingUsername
member.summary: The Binding Request contained a MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute, but not a USERNAME attribute. Both must be present for integrity checks.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.UseTls
member.summary: The Shared Secret request has to be sent over TLS, but was not received over TLS.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.Attributes.ErrorCodeType.GlobalFailure
member.summary: The server is refusing to fulfill the request. The client should not retry.

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType
member.summary: Enumeration of any STUN attribute types Each attribute type has a matching constant defined in STUN [RFC5389] or in TURN [RFC5766]

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Unmanaged
member.summary: Represents attributes whose type is not managed by this library

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.MappedAddress
member.summary: The MAPPED-ADDRESS attribute indicates a reflexive transport address of the client This attribute is used only by servers for achieving backwards compatibility with [RFC3489] clients.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Username
member.summary: The USERNAME attribute is used for message integrity. It identifies the username and password combination used in the message-integrity check The value of USERNAME is a variable-length value. It MUST contain a UTF-8 [RFC3629] encoded sequence of less than 513 bytes, and MUST have been processed using SASLprep [RFC4013]

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.MessageIntegrity
member.summary: The MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute contains an HMAC-SHA1 [RFC2104] of the STUN message. The MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute can be present in any STUN message type

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ErrorCode
member.summary: The ERROR-CODE attribute is used in error response messages. It contains a numeric error code value in the range of 300 to 699 plus a textual reason phrase encoded in UTF-8 [RFC3629], and is consistent in its code assignments and semantics with SIP [RFC3261] and HTTP [RFC2616].

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.UnknownAttributes
member.summary: The UNKNOWN-ATTRIBUTES attribute is present only in an error response when the response code in the ERROR-CODE attribute is 420. The attribute contains a list of 16-bit values, each of which represents an attribute type that was not understood by the server.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Realm
member.summary: The REALM attribute may be present in requests and responses. It contains text that meets the grammar for "realm-value" as described in [RFC3261] but without the double quotes and their surrounding whitespace

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Nonce
member.summary: The NONCE attribute may be present in requests and responses. It contains a sequence of qdtext or quoted-pair, which are defined in [RFC3261]. Note that this means that the NONCE attribute will not contain actual quote characters

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.XorMappedAddress
member.summary: The XOR-MAPPED-ADDRESS attribute is identical to the MAPPED-ADDRESS attribute, except that the reflexive transport address is obfuscated through the XOR function.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Software
member.summary: The SOFTWARE attribute contains a textual description of the software being used by the agent sending the message. It is used by clients and servers. Its value SHOULD include manufacturer and version number. The attribute has no impact on operation of the protocol, and serves only as a tool for diagnostic and debugging purposes

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.AlternateServer
member.summary: The alternate server represents an alternate transport address identifying a different STUN server that the STUN client should try. It is encoded in the same way as MAPPED-ADDRESS, and thus refers to a single server by IP address. The IP address family MUST be identical to that of the source IP address of the request.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.FingerPrint
member.summary: The FINGERPRINT attribute MAY be present in all STUN messages. The value of the attribute is computed as the CRC-32 of the STUN message up to (but excluding) the FINGERPRINT attribute itself, XOR'ed with the 32-bit value 0x5354554e

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ChannelNumber
member.summary: The CHANNEL-NUMBER attribute contains the number of the channel

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.LifeTime
member.summary: The LIFETIME attribute represents the duration for which the server will maintain an allocation in the absence of a refresh

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.XorPeerAddress
member.summary: The XOR-PEER-ADDRESS specifies the address and port of the peer as seen from the TURN server. (For example, the peer's server-reflexive transport address if the peer is behind a NAT.) It is encoded in the same way as XOR-MAPPED-ADDRESS [RFC5389].

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Data
member.summary: The DATA attribute is present in all Send and Data indications. The value portion of this attribute is variable length and consists of the application data (that is, the data that would immediately follow the UDP header if the data was been sent directly between the client and the peer)

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.XorRelayedAddress
member.summary: The XOR-RELAYED-ADDRESS is present in Allocate responses. It specifies the address and port that the server allocated to the client. It is encoded in the same way as XOR-MAPPED-ADDRESS [RFC5389].

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.EvenPort
member.summary: This attribute allows the client to request that the port in the relayed transport address be even, and (optionally) that the server reserve the next-higher port number

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.RequestedTransport
member.summary: This attribute is used by the client to request a specific transport protocol for the allocated transport address

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.DontFragment
member.summary: This attribute is used by the client to request that the server set the DF (Don't Fragment) bit in the IP header when relaying the application data onward to the peer

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ReservationToken
member.summary: The RESERVATION-TOKEN attribute contains a token that uniquely identifies a relayed transport address being held in reserve by the server. The server includes this attribute in a success response to tell the client about the token, and the client includes this attribute in a subsequent Allocate request to request the server use that relayed transport address for the allocation.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ConnectionId
member.summary: The CONNECTION-ID attribute uniquely identifies a peer data connection.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.RequestedAddressFamily
member.summary: The REQUESTED-ADDRESS-FAMILY attribute is used by clients to request the allocation of a specific address type from a server.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Priority
member.summary: Priority will be used by ICE to determine the order of the connectivity checks and the relative preference for candidates.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.UseCandidate
member.summary: The controlling agent MAY include the USE-CANDIDATE attribute in the Binding request. The controlled agent MUST NOT include it in its Binding request. This attribute signals that the controlling agent wishes to cease checks for this component, and use the candidate pair resulting from the check for this component

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.IceControlled
member.summary: The agent MUST include the ICE-CONTROLLED attribute in the request if it is in the controlled role

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.IceControlling
member.summary: The agent MUST include the ICE-CONTROLLING attribute in the request if it is in the controlling role

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ResponseAddress
member.summary: The RESPONSE-ADDRESS attribute indicates where the response to a Binding Request should be sent. Its syntax is identical to MAPPED-ADDRESS.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ChangeRequest
member.summary: The CHANGE-REQUEST attribute is used by the client to request that the server use a different address and/or port when sending the response

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.SourceAddress
member.summary: The SOURCE-ADDRESS attribute is present in Binding Responses. It indicates the source IP address and port that the server is sending the response from. Its syntax is identical to that of MAPPED-ADDRESS.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ChangedAddress
member.summary: The CHANGED-ADDRESS attribute indicates the IP address and port where responses would have been sent from if the "change IP" and "change port" flags had been set in the CHANGE-REQUEST attribute of the Binding Request. The attribute is always present in a Binding Response, independent of the value of the flags. Its syntax is identical to MAPPED-ADDRESS.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.Password
member.summary: The PASSWORD attribute is used in Shared Secret Responses. It is always present in a Shared Secret Response, along with the USERNAME.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.ReflectedFrom
member.summary: The REFLECTED-FROM attribute is present only in Binding Responses, when the Binding Request contained a RESPONSE-ADDRESS attribute. The attribute contains the identity (in terms of IP address) of the source where the request came from. Its purpose is to provide traceability, so that a STUN server cannot be used as a reflector for denial-of-service attacks. Its syntax is identical to the MAPPED-ADDRESS attribute.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunAttributeType.XorMappedAddressAlt
member.summary: This alternate XOR-MAPPED-ADDRESS attribute may be used in some STUN Servers implementation like Vovida or MS-TURN http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/dd909268

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.StunClient
member.summary: Represents a STUN Client that can send request to a STUN Server and receive response from it (or not)

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunClient.DEFAULT_STUN_PORT
member.summary: IANA has assigned port number 3478 for the "stun" service, defined over TCP and UDP.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunClient.DEFAULT_STUNS_PORT
member.summary: IANA has assigned port number 5349 for the "stuns" (stun-secured) service, defined over TCP and UDP. The UDP port is not currently defined. However, it is reserved for future use

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunClient.BUFFER_SIZE
member.summary: Socket receive buffer

member.name: M:Jabber.Stun.StunClient.#ctor(System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.Sockets.ProtocolType,System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2,System.Net.Security.RemoteCertificateValidationCallback)
member.summary: Constructs a StunClient
member.param: The IPEndPoint where the STUN Server can be reached
The protocol type (UDP or TCP only) used to communicate with the STUN Server

Client certificate used for mutual authentication. This certificate must be in PKCS #12 format and must contains its private key The simpler way to create a certificate of this type is to follow this makecert tutorial http://www.inventec.ch/chdh/notes/14.htm. Once your certificate is created : launch "mmc", CTRL+M, select "Certificates", add, choose "Local machine". Find your certificate under "Personal", it must have a little key in its icon, right click on it, choose "All tasks > Export...". Check the "Export key" checkbox, finish the process and then you have a valid X509Certificate2 with its private key in it
The callback handler which validate STUN Server TLS certificate

member.name: M:Jabber.Stun.StunClient.#ctor(System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.Sockets.ProtocolType,System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2,System.Net.Security.RemoteCertificateValidationCallback)
member.summary: Constructs a StunClient using an existing IPEndPoint
member.param: The IPEndPoint to which the socket will be bound to
The IPEndPoint where the STUN Server can be reached
The protocol type (UDP or TCP only) used to communicate with the STUN Server

Client certificate used for mutual authentication. This certificate must be in PKCS #12 format and must contains its private key The simpler way to create a certificate of this type is to follow this makecert tutorial http://www.inventec.ch/chdh/notes/14.htm. Once your certificate is created : launch "mmc", CTRL+M, select "Certificates", add, choose "Local machine". Find your certificate under "Personal", it must have a little key in its icon, right click on it, choose "All tasks > Export...". Check the "Export key" checkbox, finish the process and then you have a valid X509Certificate2 with its private key in it
The callback handler which validate STUN Server TLS certificate

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.StunMessage
member.summary: Represents a message according to STUN [RFC5389], TURN [RFC5766], TURN-TCP [RFC6062], TURN-IPV6 [RFC6156], ICE [RFC5245] and STUN Classic [RFC3489]

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMessage.MAGIC_COOKIE
member.summary: The magic cookie field MUST contain the fixed value 0x2112A442 in network byte order. In [RFC3489], this field was part of the transaction ID. Placing the magic cookie allows a server to detect if the client will understand certain attributes that were added in specification [RFC5389]

member.name: M:Jabber.Stun.StunMessage.AddMessageIntegrity(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Add the MESSAGE-INTEGRITY attribute to the message. This should be fired just before a call to StunClient.SendMessage as it needs existing attribute to be computed. But these attributes MUST be added before the MESSAGE-ATTRIBUTE except for FINGERPRINT attribute which MUST be added at the end of the StunMessage and also used in the MESSAGE-INTEGRITY computation
member.param: The password used to authenticate the StunMessage
True if this StunMessage should authenticate using longterm credentials

member.summary: Contains the method class this message encapsulates

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.StunMessage.MessageLength
member.summary: Contains the size, in bytes, of the message not including the 20-byte STUN header

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.StunMessage.TransactionID
member.summary: The transaction ID is a 96-bit (12byte) identifier, used to uniquely identify STUN transactions. * For request/response transactions, the transaction ID is chosen by the STUN client for the request and echoed by the server in the response. * For indications, it is chosen by the agent sending the indication.

member.name: P:Jabber.Stun.StunMessage.MappedAddress
member.summary: Contains a MAPPED-ADDRESS or XOR-MAPPED-ADDRESS attribute if this message contains one of these The XOR-MAPPED-ADDRESS is parsed prior to MAPPED-ADDRESS

member.name: T:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType
member.summary: Enumeration of any STUN message types Each method type has a matching constant defined in STUN [RFC5389] and in TURN [RFC5766]

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Unmanaged
member.summary: Represents methods whose type is not managed by this library

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Binding
member.summary: Binding requests are used to determine the bindings allocated by NATs. The client sends a Binding Request to the server, over UDP or TCP. The server examines the source IP address and port of the request, and copies them into a response that is sent back to the client

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Allocate
member.summary: Only request/response semantics defined All TURN operations revolve around allocations, and all TURN messages are associated with an allocation. An allocation conceptually consists of the following state data: * the relayed transport address * the 5-tuple: (client's IP address, client's port, server IP address, server port, transport protocol) * the authentication information * the time-to-expiry * a list of permissions * a list of channel to peer bindings.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Refresh
member.summary: Only request/response semantics defined A Refresh transaction can be used to either (a) refresh an existing allocation and update its time-to-expiry or (b) delete an existing allocation

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Send
member.summary: Only indication semantics defined The client can use a Send indication to pass data to the server for relaying to a peer. A client may use a Send indication even if a channel is bound to that peer

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Data
member.summary: Only indication semantics defined If relaying is permitted but no channel is bound to a peer, then the server forms and sends a Data indication

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.CreatePermission
member.summary: Only request/response semantics defined TURN supports two ways for the client to install or refresh permissions on the server

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.ChannelBind
member.summary:
Only request/response semantics defined Channels provide a way for the client and server to send application data using ChannelData messages, which have less overhead than Send and Data indications.
A channel binding consists of: * a channel number; * a transport address (of the peer); and * A time-to-expiry timer.

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.Connect
member.summary: To initiate a TCP connection to a peer, a client MUST send a Connect request over the control connection for the desired allocation. The Connect request MUST include an XOR-PEER-ADDRESS attribute containing the transport address of the peer to which a connection is desired. If the connection is successfully established, the client will receive a success response. That response will contain a CONNECTION-ID attribute

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.ConnectionBind
member.summary: The client MUST initiate a new TCP connection to the server that MUST be made using a different local transport address. Authentication of the client by the server MUST use the same method and credentials as for the control connection. Once established, the client MUST send a ConnectionBind request over the new connection. That request MUST include the CONNECTION-ID attribute, echoed from the Connect Success response

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.ConnectionAttempt
member.summary: After an Allocate request is successfully processed by the server, the client will start receiving a ConnectionAttempt indication each time a peer for which a permission has been installed attempts a new connection to the relayed transport address. This indication will contain CONNECTION-ID and XOR-PEER-ADDRESS attributes

member.name: F:Jabber.Stun.StunMethodType.SharedSecret
member.summary: Shared Secret Requests ask the server to return a temporary username and password. This username and password are used in a subsequent Binding Request and Binding Response, for the purposes of authentication and message integrity

member.name: M:Jabber.Stun.StunUtilities.GetMappedAddressFrom(System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.Sockets.ProtocolType)
member.summary: Helper method using UDP or TCP that returns needed informations to begin peer-to-peer Punch Hole operations using an existing IPEndPoint
member.param: The IPEndPoint to which the socket will be bound to
The IP Address of the STUN server
The connection type used to do the STUN Binding Request
member.returns: A key-value pair where : * the key is the local IPEndPoint from where the STUN request occurs * the value is the MappedAddress IPEndPoint returned by the STUN server

member.name: M:Jabber.Stun.StunUtilities.GetMappedAddressFrom(System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.IPEndPoint,System.Net.Security.RemoteCertificateValidationCallback,System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.X509Certificate2)
member.summary: Helper method using TLS over TCP that returns needed informations to begin peer-to-peer Punch Hole operations using an existing IPEndPoint
member.param: The IPEndPoint to which the socket will be bound to
The IP Address of the STUN server
The callback handler which validate STUN Server TLS certificate

Client certificate used for mutual authentication. This certificate must be in PKCS #12 format and must contains its private key The simpler way to create a certificate of this type is to follow this makecert tutorial http://www.inventec.ch/chdh/notes/14.htm. Once your certificate is created : launch "mmc", CTRL+M, select "Certificates", add, choose "Local machine". Find your certificate under "Personal", it must have a little key in its icon, right click on it, choose "All tasks > Export...". Check the "Export key" checkbox, finish the process and then you have a valid X509Certificate2 with its private key in it
member.returns: A key-value pair where : * the key is the local IPEndPoint from where the STUN request occurs * the value is the MappedAddress IPEndPoint returned by the STUN server

member.name: T:Bedrock.Collections.LinkedList
member.summary: A doubly-linked list implementation, with a sentinal wrap-around m_header. Yes, it does seem like this should have been included in System.Collections. This may be a nicer implementation of Queue than the one in System.Collections, which uses an array. YMMV.

member.summary: Summary description for SkipList.

member.name: F:Bedrock.Collections.SkipList.DEFAULT_PROBABILITY
member.summary: The default probability for adding new node levels. .25 provides a good balance of speed and size. .5 will be slightly less variable in run time, and take up more space

member.name: F:Bedrock.Collections.SkipList.DEFAULT_MAX_LEVEL
member.summary: The maximum depth for searching. log(1/p, n), where n is the max number of expected nodes. For the defaults, n = 4096. The list will continue to work for larger lists, but performance will start to degrade toward that of a linear search to further you get above n. TODO: automatically reset max_level when Length goes above n.

member.name: M:Bedrock.Collections.TrieNode.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary:
Compares the specified object with this entry for equality. Returns true if the given object is also a map entry and the two entries represent the same mapping. More formally, two entries e1 and e2 represent the same mapping if: (e1.getKey()==null ? e2.getKey()==null : e1.getKey().equals(e2.getKey())) && (e1.getValue()==null ? e2.getValue()==null : e1.getValue().equals(e2.getValue()))
This ensures that the equals method works properly across different implementations of the Map.Entry interface.
member.param: Object to be compared for equality with this map entry.
member.returns: True if the specified object is equal to this map entry; otherwise false.

member.returns: Hash code.

member.name: T:Bedrock.Net.SocketWatcher
member.summary: A collection of sockets. This makes a lot more sense in the poll() version (Unix/C) since you need to have a place to collect all of the sockets and call poll(). Here, it's just convenience functions.

member.name: M:Bedrock.Net.SocketWatcher.#ctor
member.summary: Create a new instance, which will manage an unlimited number of sockets.

member.name: M:Bedrock.Net.SocketWatcher.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Create a new instance.
member.param: Maximum number of sockets to watch. In this version, this is mostly for rate-limiting purposes.

member.name: M:Bedrock.Net.SocketWatcher.SetCertificateFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Set the certificate to be used for accept sockets. To generate a test .pfx file using openssl, add this to openssl.conf:
[ serverex ] extendedKeyUsage=1.3.6.1.5.5.7.3.1
and run the following commands:
openssl req -new -x509 -newkey rsa:1024 -keyout privkey.pem -out key.pem -extensions serverex openssl pkcs12 -export -in key.pem -inkey privkey.pem -name localhost -out localhost.pfx
If you leave the certificate null, and you are doing Accept, the SSL class will try to find a default server cert on your box. If you have IIS installed with a cert, this might just go...
member.param: The password, if this is a .pfx file, null if .cer file.

member.name: M:Bedrock.Net.SocketWatcher.SetCertificateStore(System.Security.Cryptography.X509Certificates.StoreName)
member.summary: Set the certificate from a system store. Try "MY" for the ones listed in IE.

member.name: T:Bedrock.Util.GetOpt
member.summary: GetOpt should be subclassed to create a class that handles command-line parameters. The subclass should use fields or properties that have the CommandLine attribute set on them. Fields and properties of type bool will be toggle flags, other types will take a value as either the next command-line parameter or following a colon. Also, now, you can create an instance of GetOpt, and pass in TODO: Give examples of sublcass and calling example.

member.summary: Nick JID. room@conference/nick.

member.summary: Whenver we change presence, send the new presence to the room, including caps etc.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.Room.Configure
member.summary: Configures the room. OnRoomConfig MUST be set first. OnRoomConfig will be called back in the GUI thread if there is an InvokeControl on your XmppStream. Make sure that OnRoomConfig does not return until it has the answer, typically by popping up a modal dialog with the x:data form.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.Room.FinishConfigDefault
member.summary: Finish up configuration, taking the default room config. Also known as an "Instant Room". Suitable for use if the user cancels the configuration request, perhaps.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.Room.Join
member.summary: Joins the room. If the room is created, Configure() will be called automatically.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.Room.Join(System.String)
member.summary: Join a room, using a password.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.Room.Leave(System.String)
member.summary: Exits the room. This cleans up the entry in the ConferenceManager, as well.
member.param: Reason for leaving the room. May be null for no reason.

member.name: M:Jabber.Connection.Room.PublicMessage(System.String)
member.summary: Sends a message to everyone currently in the room.

member.summary: Sends a private message to a single user in the room.

The reason for the invite, or null for none.

member.summary: Change the role of a user in the room, by nickname. Must be a moderator.

member.summary: Modify the roles of the parties in this list. To use, retrive a ParticipantCollection, change the roles of the parties in that collection, then pass that modified collection in here.

member.summary: Contains the port number to connect to or to listen on.

member.summary: Uses SSL on connection if set to true.

member.name: F:Jabber.Connection.Options.AUTO_TLS
member.summary: Uses Start-TLS on connection if set to true and the server supports it.

member.name: F:Jabber.Connection.Options.AUTO_COMPRESS
member.summary: Starts the XMPP stream compression (XEP-138) on connection if set to true.

member.summary: Allows plaintext authentication for connecting to the XMPP server.

member.summary: Attempts a SASL connection if set to true and the feature is available from the XMPP server. If the server doesn't support SASL, the connection will move to a fallback mechanism.

member.name: F:Jabber.Connection.Options.REQUIRE_SASL
member.summary: Requires SASL authentication on this connection if set to true. There is no fallback mechanism. If the server doesn't support SASL, the connection attempt will fail.

member.summary: Contains the list of SASL Mechanisms such as Digest-MD5, Plain and so on.

member.name: T:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType
member.summary: These error conditions may be read by constrained clients. They are used for connection manager problems, abstracting stream errors, communication problems between the connection manager and the server, and invalid client requests (binding syntax errors, possible attacks, etc.)

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.UNSPECIFIED
member.summary: None specified

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.host_gone
member.summary: The target domain specified in the 'to' attribute or the target host or port specified in the 'route' attribute is no longer serviced by the connection manager.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.host_unknown
member.summary: The target domain specified in the 'to' attribute or the target host or port specified in the 'route' attribute is unknown to the connection manager.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.improper_addressing
member.summary: The initialization element lacks a 'to' or 'route' attribute (or the attribute has no value) but the connection manager requires one.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.internal_server_error
member.summary: The connection manager has experienced an internal error that prevents it from servicing the request.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.remote_connection_failed
member.summary: The connection manager was unable to connect to, or unable to connect securely to, or has lost its connection to, the server.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.remote_stream_error
member.summary: Encapsulates an error in the protocol being transported.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.see_other_uri
member.summary: The connection manager does not operate at this URI (e.g., the connection manager accepts only SSL or TLS connections at some https: URI rather than the http: URI requested by the client). The client may try POSTing to the URI in the content of the child element.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.system_shutdown
member.summary: The connection manager is being shut down. All active HTTP sessions are being terminated. No new sessions can be created.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.ConditionType.undefined_condition
member.summary: The error is not one of those defined herein; the connection manager SHOULD include application-specific information in the content of the wrapper.

member.name: T:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.BodyType
member.summary: Is this an error or a termination?

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.BodyType.UNSPECIFIED
member.summary: None specified

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.BodyType.error
member.summary: Error encapsulated in response

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.BodyType.terminate
member.summary: Terminate the stream

member.name: T:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body
member.summary: An HTTP Binding body element, which encapsulates stanzas. See XEP-124 and XEP-206 for details.

member.name: M:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.#ctor(System.Xml.XmlDocument)
member.summary: Create for outbound

member.name: M:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.#ctor(System.String,System.Xml.XmlQualifiedName,System.Xml.XmlDocument)
member.summary: Create inbound instance

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Contents
member.summary: The child elements of the body. 0 or more stanzas.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Accept
member.summary: The content encodings that server can handle.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Ack
member.summary: Acknowledgement of a given RID.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.AuthID
member.summary: Stream ID for digest auth calculations

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Charsets
member.summary: The charsets supported by the server. Almost always just UTF8, if it exists.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Condition
member.summary: The error condition, if this is an error.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.From
member.summary: A client MAY include a 'from' attribute to enable the connection manager to forward its identity to the server.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Hold
member.summary: This attribute specifies the maximum number of requests the connection manager is allowed to keep waiting at any one time during the session. If the client is not able to use HTTP Pipelining then this SHOULD be set to "1".

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Inactivity
member.summary: This attribute specifies the longest allowable inactivity period (in seconds). This enables the client to ensure that the periods with no requests pending are never too long (see Polling Sessions and Inactivity).

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Key
member.summary: The client MUST set the 'key' attribute of all subsequent requests to the value of the next key in the generated sequence (decrementing from K(n-1) towards K(1) with each request sent).

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.MaxPause
member.summary: If the connection manager supports session pausing (see Inactivity) then it SHOULD advertise that to the client by including a 'maxpause' attribute in the session creation response element. The value of the attribute indicates the maximum length of a temporary session pause (in seconds) that a client MAY request.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.NewKey
member.summary: The client MUST set the 'newkey' attribute of the first request in the session to the value K(n).

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Pause
member.summary: If a client encounters an exceptional temporary situation during which it will be unable to send requests to the connection manager for a period of time greater than the maximum inactivity period (e.g., while a runtime environment changes from one web page to another), and if the connection manager included a 'maxpause' attribute in its Session Creation Response, then the client MAY request a temporary increase to the maximum inactivity period by including a 'pause' attribute in a request.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Polling
member.summary: This attribute specifies the shortest allowable polling interval (in seconds). This enables the client to not send empty request elements more often than desired.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Report
member.summary: After receiving a request with an 'ack' value less than the 'rid' of the last request that it has already responded to, the connection manager MAY inform the client of the situation by sending its next response immediately instead of waiting until it has stanzas to send to the client (e.g., if some time has passed since it responded). In this case it SHOULD include a 'report' attribute set to one greater than the 'ack' attribute it received from the client, and a 'time' attribute set to the number of milliseconds since it sent the response associated with the 'report' attribute.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Requests
member.summary: This attribute enables the connection manager to limit the number of simultaneous requests the client makes. The RECOMMENDED values are either "2" or one more than the value of the 'hold' attribute specified in the session request.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.RID
member.summary: Request ID. Needs to start out random, and increment by one for each new BOSH request.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Route
member.summary: connection manager MAY be configured to enable sessions with more than one server in different domains. When requesting a session with such a 'proxy' connection manager, a client SHOULD include a 'route' attribute that specifies the protocol, hostname, and port of the server with which it wants to communicate, formatted as "proto:host:port" (e.g., "xmpp:jabber.org:9999").

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Secure
member.summary: A client MAY include a 'secure' attribute to specify that communications between the connection manager and the server must be "secure". (Note: The 'secure' attribute is of type xs:boolean (see XML Schema Part 2) and the default value is "false". [17]) If a connection manager receives a session request with the 'secure' attribute set to "true" or "1", then it MUST respond to the client with a remote-connection-failed error as soon as it determines that it cannot communicate in a secure way with the server.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.SID
member.summary: Stream ID

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Stream
member.summary:
If a connection manager supports the multi-streams feature, it MUST include a 'stream' attribute in its Session Creation Response. If a client does not receive the 'stream' attribute then it MUST assume that the connection manager does not support the feature. [22]
The 'stream' attribute identifies the first stream to be opened for the session. The value of each 'stream' attribute MUST be an opaque and unpredictable name that is unique within the context of the connection manager application.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Time
member.summary: After receiving a request with an 'ack' value less than the 'rid' of the last request that it has already responded to, the connection manager MAY inform the client of the situation by sending its next response immediately instead of waiting until it has stanzas to send to the client (e.g., if some time has passed since it responded). In this case it SHOULD include a 'report' attribute set to one greater than the 'ack' attribute it received from the client, and a 'time' attribute set to the number of milliseconds since it sent the response associated with the 'report' attribute.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.To
member.summary: This attribute specifies the target domain of the first stream.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Type
member.summary: At any time, the client MAY gracefully terminate the session by sending a element with a 'type' attribute set to "terminate". The termination request MAY include one or more stanzas that the connection manager MUST forward to the server to ensure graceful logoff.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Ver
member.summary: This attribute specifies the highest version of the BOSH protocol that the client supports. The numbering scheme is "major.minor" (where the minor number MAY be incremented higher than a single digit, so it MUST be treated as a separate integer). Note: The 'ver' attribute should not be confused with the version of any protocol being transported.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.Stream.Body.Wait
member.summary: This attribute specifies the longest time (in seconds) that the connection manager is allowed to wait before responding to any request during the session. This enables the client to limit the delay before it discovers any network failure, and to prevent its HTTP/TCP connection from expiring due to inactivity.

member.name: T:Jabber.Protocol.X.EventType
member.summary: Types of events

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.X.EventType.NONE
member.summary: No event type specified.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.X.EventType.offline
member.summary: Indicates that the message has been stored offline by the server, because the intended recipient is not available. This event is to be raised by the Jabber server.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.X.EventType.delivered
member.summary: Indicates that the message has been delivered to the recipient. This signifies that the message has reached the Jabber client, but does not necessarily mean that the message has been displayed. This event is to be raised by the Jabber client.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.X.EventType.displayed
member.summary: Once the message has been received by the Jabber client, it may be displayed to the user. This event indicates that the message has been displayed, and is to be raised by the Jabber client. Even if a message is displayed multiple times, this event should only be raised once.

member.name: F:Jabber.Protocol.X.EventType.composing
member.summary: In threaded chat conversations, this indicates that the recipient is composing a reply to a message that was just sent. The event is to be raised by the Jabber client. A Jabber client is allowed to raise this event multiple times in response to the same request, providing that a specific sequence is followed.

member.name: T:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event
member.summary: A event x element, described by XEP-0022.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event.ID
member.summary: The message to which this event refers.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event.Type
member.summary: The type of the event.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event.IsOffline
member.summary: Indicates that the message has been stored offline by the server, because the intended recipient is not available. This event is to be raised by the Jabber server.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event.IsDelivered
member.summary: Indicates that the message has been delivered to the recipient. This signifies that the message has reached the Jabber client, but does not necessarily mean that the message has been displayed. This event is to be raised by the Jabber client.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event.IsDisplayed
member.summary: Once the message has been received by the Jabber client, it may be displayed to the user. This event indicates that the message has been displayed, and is to be raised by the Jabber client. Even if a message is displayed multiple times, this event should only be raised once.

member.name: P:Jabber.Protocol.X.Event.IsComposing
member.summary: In threaded chat conversations, this indicates that the recipient is composing a reply to a message that was just sent. The event is to be raised by the Jabber client. A Jabber client is allowed to raise this event multiple times in response to the same request, providing that a specific sequence is followed.

member.name: M:StringPrep.Steps.BidiStep.Prepare(System.Text.StringBuilder)
member.summary:
Perform BiDi checks.
From RFC 3454, Section 6: In any profile that specifies bidirectional character handling, all three of the following requirements MUST be met:
The characters in section 5.8 MUST be prohibited.
If a string contains any RandALCat character, the string MUST NOT contain any LCat character.
If a string contains any RandALCat character, a RandALCat character MUST be the first character of the string, and a RandALCat character MUST be the last character of the string.

member.summary: Data for composition of characters. The algorithms here are still black box to me.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.FIRST_START
member.summary: Where the first range of offsets from Data starts. These are used for checking the first character in a pair with a second character in Array.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.FIRST_SINGLE_START
member.summary: Where the offsets of the range of characters where there is only one match for the second character, with a given first character.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.SECOND_START
member.summary: Where the offsets of the range of second characters that match a given first character starts.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.SECOND_SINGLE_START
member.summary: When there is only a single match to the left for these characters on the right, the offsets for that chunk of characters starts here.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.Data
member.summary: The offset into Array for each character. This array is compressed using the Table table, which provides page offsets for the pages that are non-zero.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.Table
member.summary: Page offsets into Data for each page of characters.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.FirstSingle
member.summary: When the offset for the first character is in the range [FIRST_SINGLE_START, SECOND_START), look up the corresponding character here with the offset from Data to see if it is the second character. If not, there is no combination.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.SecondSingle
member.summary: When the offset for the second character is in the range [SECOND_SINGLE_START...), look up the corresponding character here with the offset from Data to see if it is the first character. If not, there is no combination.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.ComposeData.Array
member.summary: Array of composition pairs, indexed by offset (from Data) of first character, and offset of second character.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.DecomposeData.Offsets
member.summary: Offset into the Expansion string for each decomposable character. One way to make this faster might be to have this not be sparse, so that the lookup could be direct rather than a binary search. That would add several hundred K to the library size, though, or time at startup to initialize an array from this.

member.name: F:StringPrep.Unicode.DecomposeData.Expansion
member.summary: How to expand characters. Since multiple input characters output the same string, this table is compressed to only have one copy of each, and the Offsets table gives offsets into this for each input.

members.member: Represents one or more characters of data.
Represents a newline (CR, LF or CR followed by LF) in data.
Represents a complete start-tag <name>, that doesn't have any attribute specifications.
Represents a complete start-tag <name att="val">, that contains one or more attribute specifications.
Represents an empty element tag <name/>, that doesn't have any attribute specifications.
Represents an empty element tag <name att="val"/>, that contains one or more attribute specifications.
Represents a complete end-tag </name>.
Represents the start of a CDATA section <![CDATA[.
Represents the end of a CDATA section ]]>.
Represents a general entity reference.
Represents a general entity reference to a one of the 5 predefined entities amp, lt, gt, quot, apos.
Represents a numeric character reference (decimal or hexadecimal), when the referenced character is less than or equal to 0xFFFF and so is represented by a single char.
Represents a numeric character reference (decimal or hexadecimal), when the referenced character is greater than 0xFFFF and so is represented by a pair of chars.
Represents a processing instruction.
Represents an XML declaration or text declaration (a processing instruction whose target is xml).
Represents a comment <!-- comment -->. This can occur both in the prolog and in content.
Represents a white space character in an attribute value, excluding white space characters that are part of line boundaries.
Represents a parameter entity reference in the prolog.
Represents whitespace in the prolog. The token contains one or more whitespace characters.
Represents <!NAME in the prolog.
Represents > in the prolog.
Represents a name in the prolog.
Represents a name token in the prolog that is not a name.
Represents #NAME in the prolog.
Represents | in the prolog.
Represents a % in the prolog that does not start a parameter entity reference. This can occur in an entity declaration.
Represents a ( in the prolog.
Represents a ) in the prolog that is not followed immediately by any of *, + or ?.
Represents [ in the prolog.
Represents ] in the prolog.
Represents a literal (EntityValue, AttValue, SystemLiteral or PubidLiteral).
Represents a name followed immediately by ?.
Represents a name followed immediately by *.
Represents a name followed immediately by +.
Represents <![ in the prolog.
Represents ]]> in the prolog.
Represents )? in the prolog.
Represents )* in the prolog.
Represents )+ in the prolog.
Represents , in the prolog.
